_meta.description: Sector-specific hypothesis description templates for add-stock.js onboarding
_meta.usage: Keyed by narrative_model. Sector lookup maps sector/sectorSub strings to model keys.

T1.label: Iron Ore Supercycle
T1.description: Iron ore prices remain structurally elevated; Chinese steel demand sustains above-consensus volumes; margins expand
T1.plain_english: The bull case: China's steel demand stays stronger for longer, iron ore prices hold up, and the miner earns well above what the market currently expects.
T1.what_to_watch: Monthly Chinese steel production data, iron ore spot price vs. futures curve, port inventory levels at Qingdao.

T2.label: Managed Transition
T2.description: Iron ore prices normalise toward $85-100/t long-run; volumes grow modestly; returns held up by capital discipline
T2.plain_english: The base case: prices drift lower but the company manages costs and capital allocation well enough to maintain solid shareholder returns.
T2.what_to_watch: C1 cash costs per tonne, quarterly production guidance, dividend payout ratio vs. peers.

T3.label: China Demand Destruction
T3.description: Structural decline in Chinese property sector reduces steel intensity; iron ore prices fall below $80/t; margins compress sharply
T3.plain_english: The bear case: Chinese construction stays in a prolonged slump, steel demand falls, and iron ore prices collapse to levels where margins are thin.
T3.what_to_watch: Chinese property starts and completions data, blast furnace utilisation rates, Chinese government stimulus announcements.

T4.label: Green Steel Disruption
T4.description: Accelerating shift to electric arc furnaces and direct reduced iron reduces high-grade coking coal/iron ore premium; stranded asset risk emerges
T4.plain_english: The structural shift case: the global steel industry decarbonises faster than expected, changing which type of iron ore is most valuable.
T4.what_to_watch: Global DRI capacity additions, green hydrogen cost curve, EU carbon border adjustment mechanism timeline.

T1.label: Commodity Super-Cycle
T1.description: Broad commodity price strength driven by supply discipline and energy transition demand; earnings beat consensus
T1.plain_english: The bull case: commodity prices stay strong, energy transition demand for copper and other metals offsets any China weakness.
T1.what_to_watch: Copper/nickel/lithium spot prices, LME inventory levels, Chinese manufacturing PMI.

T2.label: Through-Cycle Compounder
T2.description: Commodity prices cycle around long-run averages; company maintains margins through disciplined cost management and portfolio diversification
T2.plain_english: The base case: commodity prices cycle as expected and the company's diversified portfolio buffers through downturns.
T2.what_to_watch: Cost-per-unit across major segments, portfolio mix vs. spot price moves, capital allocation decisions.

T3.label: Commodity Price Collapse
T3.description: Commodity prices fall materially below consensus on demand shock or supply surge; earnings and dividends cut
T3.plain_english: The bear case: commodity prices fall enough to force dividend cuts and capex deferrals.
T3.what_to_watch: Global manufacturing activity, inventory build at major customers, supply-side production decisions by majors.

T4.label: Critical Minerals Re-Rating
T4.description: Energy transition creates structural demand surge for specific commodities (copper, lithium, nickel); company re-rates as critical minerals supplier
T4.plain_english: The upside catalyst: the market reprices the company as a key energy transition supplier, re-rating the stock.
T4.what_to_watch: EV penetration rates, battery gigafactory build-out, government critical minerals policy.

T1.label: NIM Expansion + Credit Quality
T1.description: Rate environment sustains above-cycle net interest margins; credit losses remain contained; ROE expands toward top-of-cycle
T1.plain_english: The bull case: the bank earns strong margins, bad debts stay low, and capital is returned to shareholders at an above-average rate.
T1.what_to_watch: Net interest margin trajectory at results, mortgage pricing vs. funding costs, 90-day arrears trend.

T2.label: Steady Returns, Compressed Margins
T2.description: NIMs gradually normalise as rate cuts flow through; credit quality holds; ROE settles at mid-cycle; fully priced at current levels
T2.plain_english: The base case: the bank delivers steady but unexciting returns as margins compress from cycle highs.
T2.what_to_watch: RBA rate decisions and timing of first cut, mortgage market competition and switching rates, CET1 capital ratios.

T3.label: Credit Cycle Deterioration
T3.description: Unemployment rises; mortgage stress increases; credit losses spike above provisioning; ROE falls; capital position pressured
T3.plain_english: The bear case: the Australian economy weakens enough that mortgage defaults and business failures hit bank earnings.
T3.what_to_watch: Monthly ABS unemployment data, household debt serviceability ratios, business insolvency filings.

T4.label: Fintech Margin Compression
T4.description: Digital-first banks and buy-now-pay-later platforms structurally erode retail banking margins; incumbent loses market share in key segments
T4.plain_english: The structural threat: new entrants gradually take profitable customers, eroding the franchise's long-term earning power.
T4.what_to_watch: New entrant deposit/mortgage market share data, regulatory treatment of neobanks, customer acquisition cost trends.

T1.label: Capital Markets Re-Rating
T1.description: Capital markets activity accelerates; deal flow, ECM, and M&A advisory revenues surge; asset management AUM grows above expectations
T1.plain_english: The bull case: deal markets reopen, AUM grows, and the diversified revenue model earns above-cycle returns.
T1.what_to_watch: ASX IPO pipeline, M&A transaction volumes, AUM flows by asset class, investment banking revenue vs. peers.

T2.label: Through-Cycle Franchise
T2.description: Diversified revenue model buffers through market cycles; returns stay above cost of capital; capital allocation remains disciplined
T2.plain_english: The base case: the diversified model keeps generating solid returns even when individual segments soften.
T2.what_to_watch: ROE vs. cost of equity, dividend payout sustainability, credit provision levels in lending book.

T3.label: Capital Markets Winter
T3.description: Sustained market volatility and high rates suppress deal activity; trading losses; AUM redemptions; earnings fall sharply
T3.plain_english: The bear case: a prolonged market downturn kills deal flow and hits trading and AUM revenues simultaneously.
T3.what_to_watch: Global M&A deal volumes, equity market volatility (VIX), fund outflow trends, credit spread widening.

T4.label: Platform Disruption
T4.description: Technology platforms compress advisory margins; passive investing growth reduces AUM fee rates; structural revenue pool shrinks
T4.plain_english: The structural threat: technology and passive investing trends permanently reduce the revenue available to traditional financial intermediaries.
T4.what_to_watch: Fee rate trends across AUM, ETF market share vs. active management, robo-advice platform growth.

T1.label: Rule-of-40 Compounder
T1.description: Revenue growth + FCF margin consistently exceeds 40; international expansion lands above expectations; multiple expansion justified
T1.plain_english: The bull case: the company grows fast and generates cash at the same time, justifying a premium valuation that keeps expanding.
T1.what_to_watch: ARR growth rate vs. consensus, net revenue retention rate, international segment growth vs. domestic.

T2.label: Profitable Growth Normalisation
T2.description: Growth moderates as market matures; margins expand as growth investment slows; FCF improves but re-rating limited
T2.plain_english: The base case: growth is good but not exceptional, and the stock is fairly valued for what it delivers.
T2.what_to_watch: Customer churn rate, sales efficiency metrics, FCF conversion vs. EBITDA margin progression.

T3.label: Growth Deceleration De-rating
T3.description: Competitive pressure or market saturation slows growth below 20%; premium multiple contracts sharply; earnings disappoint
T3.plain_english: The bear case: growth disappoints and the market brutally reprices a high-multiple stock downward.
T3.what_to_watch: Net new ARR each quarter, customer acquisition cost trends, competitive win/loss rates in key verticals.

T4.label: AI Platform Disruption
T4.description: AI-native competitors or incumbents building AI-first products undercut pricing and product differentiation; TAM assumptions challenged
T4.plain_english: The existential threat: AI makes core functionality commoditised or enables a cheaper alternative to win customers.
T4.what_to_watch: AI feature launches by direct competitors, customer survey data on AI tool usage, pricing pressure in key segments.

T1.label: Pipeline Catalyst + Market Expansion
T1.description: Clinical or commercial milestones beat expectations; geographic expansion drives above-consensus revenue; R&D pipeline de-risked
T1.plain_english: The bull case: key products perform above expectations and the pipeline delivers the next growth leg.
T1.what_to_watch: Clinical trial readout dates, US/international revenue growth rates, pipeline milestone events.

T2.label: Steady Compounder
T2.description: Core products grow in line with market; franchise durability maintained; R&D spend held at sustainable levels; FCF generation solid
T2.plain_english: The base case: the company compounds steadily, growing in line with the market without any major surprises.
T2.what_to_watch: Product volume and pricing trends, patent cliff timeline, biosimilar competition.

T3.label: Competitive Erosion
T3.description: Biosimilar entry or competitive products erode key franchise revenue; pricing pressure compresses margins; R&D fails to replace revenue
T3.plain_english: The bear case: competition (biosimilars, new entrants) takes market share from core products faster than the pipeline can offset.
T3.what_to_watch: Biosimilar approval timelines, competitor product launches, pricing trends in core markets.

T4.label: Regulatory or Clinical Setback
T4.description: FDA/TGA rejection or clinical failure of key pipeline asset; revenue assumptions reset; multiple contracts sharply
T4.plain_english: The tail risk: a negative regulatory or clinical outcome forces a major revision of revenue and valuation assumptions.
T4.what_to_watch: Regulatory agency decision dates, Phase 3 trial interim data, FDA advisory committee meetings.

T1.label: Volume Recovery + Margin Expansion
T1.description: Cost-of-living pressures ease; consumer confidence recovers; private label mix improvement drives margin; loyalty platform monetised
T1.plain_english: The bull case: cost pressures ease, customers return to premium products, and the loyalty/data platform becomes a meaningful earnings driver.
T1.what_to_watch: Same-store sales growth vs. volume/price split, private label penetration rate, Everyday Rewards/loyalty platform metrics.

T2.label: Managed Competitive Position
T2.description: Duopoly maintains pricing discipline; gross margins stable; e-commerce growing; international remains stable contributor
T2.plain_english: The base case: the supermarket holds its market position and earns stable returns, with e-commerce gradually becoming more important.
T2.what_to_watch: Market share data (Woolworths/Coles/Aldi/Costco split), EBIT margin by segment, e-commerce penetration.

T3.label: Margin Squeeze + Market Share Loss
T3.description: Aldi/Costco/online players take share; supplier negotiations fail; regulatory scrutiny increases costs; earnings disappoint
T3.plain_english: The bear case: the discounters keep winning share, and regulatory pressure on supermarket pricing further limits margin recovery.
T3.what_to_watch: ACCC supermarket pricing review outcomes, Aldi store count growth, customer satisfaction scores.

T4.label: Grocery Platform Disruption
T4.description: Quick-commerce, direct-to-consumer FMCG brands, or AI-powered meal planning platforms structurally reduce basket size and frequency
T4.plain_english: The structural threat: technology changes how Australians shop for food, eroding the supermarket's role as the default destination.
T4.what_to_watch: Quick-commerce delivery penetration (HelloFresh, DoorDash Grocery), direct-brand D2C growth, meal kit market size.

T1.label: Franchisee Network Expansion
T1.description: New store rollout exceeds plan; same-store sales accelerate above inflation; franchisee economics attract new partners; margin expands at corporate level
T1.plain_english: The bull case: the store network grows fast, sales per store are strong, and the franchise model generates more cash than the market expects.
T1.what_to_watch: Net new store openings vs. plan, same-store sales growth (volume vs. price), franchisee profitability metrics.

T2.label: Steady Growth at Fair Value
T2.description: Network expansion on plan; same-store sales grow in line with food inflation; franchisee renewal rates healthy; returns on new stores meet hurdle
T2.plain_english: The base case: the business executes its growth plan at an acceptable pace and is fairly priced for what it delivers.
T2.what_to_watch: System sales growth, store renewal and attrition rates, digital/app ordering penetration.

T3.label: Consumer Spending Slowdown
T3.description: Cost-of-living pressures reduce discretionary food spend; same-store sales turn negative; franchisee profitability squeezed; rollout slows
T3.plain_english: The bear case: a consumer spending squeeze forces customers to cook at home, hurting both sales and franchisee viability.
T3.what_to_watch: Monthly consumer confidence data, hospitality industry sales data, franchisee closure rates.

T4.label: Delivery Platform Margin Capture
T4.description: UberEats, DoorDash platform fees structurally compress QSR restaurant economics; delivery becomes loss-making for franchisees; pricing power limited
T4.plain_english: The structural threat: third-party delivery apps capture more economics from each transaction, pressuring franchise profitability.
T4.what_to_watch: Delivery app fee rate trends, in-store vs. delivery order mix, franchisee unit economics disclosure.

T1.label: E-Commerce Tailwind + Rental Growth
T1.description: Structural logistics demand from e-commerce drives above-market rental growth; development pipeline pre-committed at strong yields; NTA expands
T1.plain_english: The bull case: demand for warehouse and logistics space stays structurally strong, and rents keep growing well above inflation.
T1.what_to_watch: Leasing spreads on renewals vs. expiries, development pipeline pre-commitment rates, vacancy rates in key markets.

T2.label: Stable REIT Compounder
T2.description: Portfolio fully leased; rental growth tracks CPI; development pipeline at acceptable returns; distribution maintained; no balance sheet stress
T2.plain_english: The base case: the trust delivers steady income and modest capital growth, as expected for a quality industrial REIT.
T2.what_to_watch: WALE (weighted average lease expiry), occupancy rate, gearing vs. covenant headroom, cost of debt.

T3.label: Cap Rate Expansion + Vacancy Rise
T3.description: Higher-for-longer interest rates push capitalisation rates higher; valuations fall; new supply enters; vacancies rise; NTA declines
T3.plain_english: The bear case: rising interest rates erode property valuations and soften the tight vacancy conditions that drove recent outperformance.
T3.what_to_watch: Cap rate benchmarks in comparable transactions, pipeline supply additions, refinancing cost on upcoming debt expiry.

T4.label: Near-Shoring + Automation Shift
T4.description: Automation of warehousing reduces space requirements per unit of goods moved; near-shoring reshuffles global logistics geography
T4.plain_english: The structural threat: robots need less warehouse space per dollar of goods, and supply chain reshuffling changes which locations are most valuable.
T4.what_to_watch: Robotic warehouse penetration rates, supply chain announcements by major tenants, port infrastructure investment.

T1.label: Occupancy Recovery + Rental Growth
T1.description: Return-to-office momentum drives occupancy above expectations; premium rents for ESG-compliant space; development yields hold up
T1.plain_english: The bull case: office demand recovers more than the market expects as employers mandate more days in the office.
T1.what_to_watch: Building access card swipe data, new lease deals and terms, % of leases with return-to-office clauses.

T2.label: Managed Portfolio, Stable Income
T2.description: Prime assets maintain high occupancy; rental income stable; balance sheet managed conservatively; distribution maintained
T2.plain_english: The base case: the high-quality portfolio keeps performing, even as the overall office market faces structural headwinds.
T2.what_to_watch: WALE by building tier, cap rate movement in comparable transactions, tenant credit quality.

T3.label: Hybrid Work Structural Oversupply
T3.description: Persistent hybrid work norms; tenants renew at smaller footprints; new supply adds vacancy; rents fall; NTA declines materially
T3.plain_english: The bear case: companies permanently reduce office space, and the combination of lower demand and new supply crushes rents and valuations.
T3.what_to_watch: Subleasing volumes (canary for future downsizing), lease expiry profile, CBD vacancy rates.

T4.label: Conversion Opportunity / Stranded Assets
T4.description: Non-prime office stock stranded by ESG requirements; conversion to residential/hotel creates value OR delays recognition of impairments
T4.plain_english: The bifurcation: prime ESG-rated space wins tenants; everything else faces structural obsolescence or costly conversion.
T4.what_to_watch: NABERS ratings across portfolio, government planning policy on residential conversion, tenant ESG commitments.

T1.label: LNG Price Strength + Volume Growth
T1.description: Asian LNG prices remain elevated; global supply disruptions extend structural tightness; new volumes ramp on plan; margins expand
T1.plain_english: The bull case: LNG prices stay high, supply stays tight globally, and the company's volumes grow as planned.
T1.what_to_watch: Asian LNG spot price (JKM), European gas storage levels, global LNG supply additions schedule.

T2.label: Managed Long-Cycle Assets
T2.description: LNG prices normalise as new supply enters; long-term contracts provide revenue floor; assets maintained; returns above cost of capital
T2.plain_english: The base case: spot prices soften but long-term contracts protect earnings, and returns stay above the cost of capital.
T2.what_to_watch: Contract vs. spot revenue mix, operating costs per barrel of oil equivalent, debt maturity profile.

T3.label: LNG Oversupply + Price Collapse
T3.description: Wave of new US/Qatar LNG supply drives prices below long-run cost support; spot revenue falls; returns on capital diminish
T3.plain_english: The bear case: a global LNG supply glut drives prices down to levels where returns are poor.
T3.what_to_watch: US LNG export capacity coming online, Qatar North Field expansion timeline, Asian demand elasticity.

T4.label: Energy Transition Stranded Asset Risk
T4.description: Accelerated renewable energy adoption reduces gas demand faster than consensus; LNG assets face shorter-than-modelled reserve life; write-downs
T4.plain_english: The long-term threat: the energy transition happens faster than assumed in the reserve life, stranding long-lived assets.
T4.what_to_watch: IEA and IRENA energy transition scenario updates, Asian government net-zero commitments, renewable capacity additions.

T1.label: Defence Spending Supercycle
T1.description: Global defence budget increases accelerate contract wins; domestic sovereign capability spending drives multi-year order book growth
T1.plain_english: The bull case: rising geopolitical tensions drive higher defence budgets globally, and the company wins a disproportionate share.
T1.what_to_watch: Australian Defence Strategic Review funding allocations, NATO defence spending commitments, contract announcement pipeline.

T2.label: Steady Contract Delivery
T2.description: Existing contract backlog delivers to schedule; renewal rates high; organic growth from contract extensions; margins stable
T2.plain_english: The base case: the company executes its existing backlog competently and wins enough new work to sustain growth.
T2.what_to_watch: Order backlog size and duration, contract margin at completion vs. bid, headcount and capability growth.

T3.label: Program Delays + Cost Overruns
T3.description: Defence program complexity leads to cost overruns; government budget reallocations delay contracts; cash conversion disappoints
T3.plain_english: The bear case: the complexity of defence programs leads to delays and cost overruns that erode margins and strain cash flow.
T3.what_to_watch: Project milestone vs. schedule, government budget review outcomes, subcontractor cost escalation.

T4.label: Autonomous Systems Disruption
T4.description: Autonomous drones and AI-driven systems replace traditional platforms; company's technology stack becomes obsolete; contract renewals at risk
T4.plain_english: The technology threat: rapid advances in autonomous and AI warfare systems render current capabilities less competitive.
T4.what_to_watch: Defence department autonomous systems strategy, competitor capability announcements, R&D spend as % of revenue.

T1.label: Infrastructure Boom Execution
T1.description: Government infrastructure pipeline drives strong order intake; margins expand on project selectivity; offshore growth adds diversification
T1.plain_english: The bull case: the infrastructure spending pipeline stays full, the company wins profitable work, and margins expand through better project selection.
T1.what_to_watch: Order backlog growth, new contract win rate, margin at completion vs. bid margin, resources vs. infrastructure revenue split.

T2.label: Steady Through-Cycle Compounder
T2.description: Diversified end markets buffer sector cycles; contract book provides revenue visibility; returns on capital above cost of capital
T2.plain_english: The base case: the diversified exposure to different infrastructure types buffers against any single sector slowdown.
T2.what_to_watch: Revenue diversification by sector, contract length and backlog cover, staff utilisation rates.

T3.label: Project Write-downs + Labour Cost Inflation
T3.description: Fixed-price contracts in inflationary environment lead to margin erosion; skill shortages create cost overruns; earnings disappoint
T3.plain_english: The bear case: labour shortages and fixed-price contract exposure combine to produce project write-downs and margin disappointments.
T3.what_to_watch: Fixed-price vs. cost-plus contract mix, wage inflation vs. contract escalation clauses, project completion risk disclosure.

T4.label: Autonomous Construction Disruption
T4.description: Robotic construction and AI-driven project management reduce labour content; traditional engineering model faces structural margin compression
T4.plain_english: The long-term structural threat: automation of construction and design reduces the value of traditional engineering labour models.
T4.what_to_watch: BIM/digital twin adoption rates, competitor automation investment, government autonomous infrastructure pilots.
